etymologies: mid 18th century; earliest use found in Tobias Smollett (1721–1771), writer. From Italian improvvisatore, †improvisatore poet who composes or performs verse extemporaneously from improvvisare + -atore

definitions: A poet who composes or performs verse extemporaneously.

notes.text: Originally and chiefly with reference to the Italian tradition of improvisational poetry which was at its height in the late 17th to mid 19th centuries.
